title: Parametric Platform Clip for Rostock Mini Acrylic Bed

description.text:
I ditched the rubber legs and use clips to hold the bed. Had the same problem at the beginning-the plate was tilting when printing larger objects.
It is very stable now except the head hitting clips sometimes when printing very large objects. I will buy a bigger piece of acryl and attach it with the same
screws that hold the motors to solve that, but for now I just have to position the object the right way before slicing.
Read more : http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?178,399454,399561#msg-399561

I used a Parametric Platform Clip with these settings:
// Parameters
Gap = 10.5;
Thickness = 4;
Reach = 25;
// Internals
Width = Gap + Thickness*2;
Height = Thickness + 10;
Change the parameters in the SCAD file to make it longer(Reach) or wider(Width).....

author: mk3v

description.text:
The "Round TO IT" is the perfect thing to give someone who says "I'll do it when I get a Round TO IT".
There's quite a few greeting cards with a circle saying "TO IT" on them but with 3D printing you can create something that better represents a tool... is round and in this case shaped like and arrow to represent going "TO IT" or making progress.
Give someone a "Round TO IT" and hopefully whatever it is they haven't got around to gets done... no excuses once they have a "Round TO IT"!
Note: Not that this has any practical use as a real tool however the base has a hole in it for a round T handle (if you want to add one) or it has flat sides so it could be turned with an adjustable wrench... or just put it on a key ring for fun.
Print with Raft but No Support. There is designed in support that should break away easily (prints great on a Replicator 2). 3 shells and 15% fill should work well for most 3D printers.

description.text:
This is a standard bike torch/ light holder designed by me. The model is designed to fit the standard 24mm bike torch and installed on the bike handlebar using cable ties.  
I printed mine using ABS and the flexibility of this model has been adjusted to fit the material. I expect it will be more brittle if you print it using PLA, however it is not wrong to try it :)  
There is slot for putting rubber (the circle slot underneath) for more grip on your handle bar. I put mine without rubber and it still grips fine.

This wrench is for adjusting the thumb-nuts on various GoPro mounting accessories.
I sometimes found I could not get enough torque on the thumb-nuts to secure my GoPro mounts to my satisfaction. This wrench was my solution.

The wrench was printed on a RepRap Huxley in about 15 minutes using 2.2 meters of PLA with a solid fill.
I plan on tweaking my settings to get a better print but the wrench works fine as is.

description.text:
This is the second version of my previous project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251150
Please go there to read the full story behind this follow-up.
Since i have the first version in daily use i 've noticed there are some "bugs" inside.
The first was, that the clamps tend to brake at the bottom clamp part. So i made the new version stronger. In the stronger shape i thought an eye would look nice - the dragon head was born ;)
Another bugging point was, that the clamps start to slip on the glass when the tension of the clamp had lost. Pla that i used to print, is not a flexible material as well and didn't bend back. (analogies with the actual i phone 6 are randomly) Also it breaks after a few bends. Anyway, i made four slots in the clamp that can be supplied with once cut o-rings. Also the the visible rest of the o-rings give them a funny look.
At least i redesigned the ring to get it fixed now in the clamp, instead in a tiny and easy to break slot.

It is recommended to print the clamp with 0,2mm layer height. 0,3 mm will work too, but the slots get not so precise ans the printer will print "in air" on the overhang of the slots.
The pin needs a little support to print.
O - rings with 2,5 mm strength will fit good in the slots. The tension is good enough if you only supply 2 slots with them. Its a bit tricky to mount the clamp with the ring shaped o-ring parts at once. Maybe you gather an other material laying around in your workshop or you glue the ring segments in before.

Figurine set-up is 20 cm high.
High polygon count 3D model and can be use for larger prints.
Use support for printing. If your printer is very well then try without.

title: K8200 power supply cover including cooling

description.text: When printing below 0,15 mm layers the stock power supply of the K8200 gets really hot and the printer stops working (mine did). To prevent this I created a new cover including ventilation. You only need one 40 mm fan and a power supply to the fan.

comments.text:
Hi Faggahz,
Thanks for your reply.
My problem was an power error in repetier (didn't have the standalone add-on by that time).
The printer stopped it's print job completely and that was end of story.
comments.author: XeO

comments.text:
Very good idea. cooling is good and increases lifetime.
in the beginning I had a lot of problems at the machine. I have found out this: At load changes down to nearly 0 (means: heater off pulses) there is a overvoltage protection in the power supply. It will switch down power for 0.3 sec. Sometimes the controller crashes down ( 1 per hour). Add a LED (with resistor) in the PSU output line. If the LED is flashing (instead of continuesly on) there is something wrong. Because of this I use annother type of PSU.

author: ColinC

description.text: LWK

This is my custom made endstop mount for Prusa i3. It is designed to be installed on the Y-axis platform as compact as possible. I get maximum movement of my bed at 180 mm with this.  
This design consist of 2 parts, it then installed together with 2x M4 bolts and nuts (see picture).  
As long as you are using the original design of Prusa i3 Y-carriage and the bearing mount you should be able to use this :)
Archive model. Not recommended for repetition.
Actual version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1731160

The project is done!
The printable area is 247 x 257 x 193mm (XYZ) (a standard MK2 hotbed at this moment).
Z-axis may be any height and depends on the belts and vertical rods lenght.
To reduce the cost of construction I changed the motor mount on Z-axis for a standard Nema17 stepper motor (without gearbox) and the counterweight system: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:798622
But with the geared motor Z-axis also works fine.
In this thing where is only Z-axis printable parts.
X and Y-axis parts are the same (except extruder mount on the block carriage). Download them here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:479294 - for lightweight alum profile.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:637350 - for standard alum profile.
New "SB47" Extruder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2658691
Extruder with geared Nema17 stepper: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:516415
Extruder with Nema17 motor (without gearbox): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:798580
PSU cover and fixers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:628747
New addon: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1014014 SolidWorks 2013 files of the SquareBOT (this version): https://grabcad.com/library/squarebot-3d-printer-2

Aluminum profile: 30x30mm length 400mm (6 pcs) (the "CONSTA" shopfitting profile, lightweight, 1.5mm thickness http://www.consta.fi/media/Consta_Systems_PDF_Catalogue.pdf)
Belts: GT2 760 - 4pcs
Pulleys: GT2 20 teeth - 8pcs (3 of them may be printed)
Stepper motors XY: NEMA17 18mm shaft (my is 0.9 degrees per step http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/9deg-nema-17-bipolar-stepper-motor-09a-36ncm51ozin-17hm150904s-p-267.html)
Stepper motor Z: geared NEMA11 (http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/gear-ratio-141-planetary-gearbox-with-nema-11-stepper-motor-11hs200674spg14-p-34.html)
I'll upload addon for using NEMA17 motor on Z-axis without gearbox soon (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:798622).
Bearings: 625ZZ - 8pcs
Rods: 10x300mm - 2pcs
Graphite Lubricating Brass Bearing: 10x14x12mm - 4pcs (like this http://www.aliexpress.com/item/5Pcs-10-14-12mm-JDB-Graphite-Lubricating-Brass-Bearing-Bushing-Sleeve-Oilless/1448887562.html)

comments.text: Has anyone actually successfully printed this?  We've tried on a MB2x with ABS many different ways including with rafts, supports, dissolvable, custom pegs to flush the heads, even slicing the bottom to anchor - no joy.  We constantly end up with a clogged head as it starts to print the very finest details of the base on an otherwise perfectly working printer.  It seems the walls are too thin to rip properly?  Would love to know if there is some magic trick - it's very cool!  :)
comments.author: cstavros

I actually have not tried :p But thanks for likeing it.
It should have even wall thickness but if you want I can upload one with thicker walls. If you promise to take a picture of it when printed ;)

comments.text: Cool - thank you!  We'll give it another shot and let you know how it goes.
comments.author: PRATRIK

comments.text: No joy.  The problem is the base; there is not enough to anchor even with rafts.  What would be cool -and maybe I'll get to trying, someday- would be to extend the inner bottom ring of the object (the opening), down to a flat/level ring that meets the plate, which would then be easy to generate a solid raft.  I think that is the limiting factor right now.  I've also tried with dissolvable as a support, but the problem is the bottom "edge" layer is so thin that it clogs the head.  Oh well, this goes in the "try it with the next printer you get" bucket :D.  Thanks for sharing anyway!

title: Simple case for Banana Pi + 2.5" HDD

description.text:
A very simple case (open) holding a Banana Pi board and a standard 2.5" HDD. Compatibility with original Banana Pi and Banana Pro has been confirmed.
See instructions for a list of parts to print and needed screws. In the pictures you see my print where side parts are made with green glow-in-the-dark PLA. Looks nice at night.

This case is very simple and easy to 3D print. You'll need to print the following parts:
How often you'll need which part

2 times bananapi_hdd_part.stl
3 times bananapi_pi_holder_1.stl
1 time bananapi_pi_holder_2.stl All parts are designed to be printed easily without support material. The STL files already contain the parts in the best orientation for printing.
Additional required parts

4 HDD screws
4 M3 x 16mm screws
4 M3 nuts
4 2.2 x 6.5 mm screws
Instructions

• Fix the 2 HDD parts to the sides of your HDD (with standard HDD screws).
  • Add the 3 pi_holder_1 and 1 pi_holder_2 parts to the HDD parts and fix them with M3 screws. The pi_holder_2 part is a bit bigger than the other 3, because the holes on the Banana Pi board are not symmetrical. Look at the board to find the one hole that is different and mount the pi_holder_2 part at the corresponding edge.
  • Last step: put the Banana Pi board on top and fix it with little 2.2x6.5mm screws. If they don't go in easily, try to screw them without Banana Pi board before and add the board later.
  • Optional: I added felt wheels to the four legs (same stuff which can be used for furniture). This way the whole thing stands softly and possible HDD vibrations don't create noise.
    Summary

    That's it.
    This case is useful for situations where you want to use your Banana Pi with HDD but don't have a place where to put them. And it's not nice to place them somewhere on the ground.

title: Valkyrie single sided surface mount stepper  board

description.text:
Re draw of Tinhead's Valkyrie stepper motor board (V2.7)to use surface mount parts in a single sided board to make it easy to fabricate yourself. This uses I2C to communicate with the main board
(see; http://letsmakerobots.com/node/9006) Because it is surface mount I added an isp header to allow programing
and just for fun I added a ftdi header.
I also added a second I2C header to allow easy daisy chaining of stepper boards.

This is untested as of yet, so use at your own risk
Please note this is designed for all sockets and pin headers (basically all through hole parts) to be mounted from the BOTTOM side of the board (opposite the surface mount parts)

title: Juicy Cocktail Stirrers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fun drinks stirrers to print in juicy translucents PLA.
There are four different designs for you to enjoy (...responsibly ;).

These stirrers are printed in two parts which snap together.
We have designed them with custom leaf rafts that easily snap off. However, for those printing on heated beds we've included the files with no raft as well.
For those with smaller print beds (e.g Printrbot) we've created a shorter stirrer (ShortStirrer.STL).
Slice with 2 shells (/perimeters) and ~10% infill. Stirrer stems can be printed at coarse resolution (0.3mm), but the tops will need to be printed at the higher resolution of 0.2mm. Created in stunning Faberdashery True Lagoon^, Lemon Drop^, Orange Fizz^ and Cherry Sour^ PLA.

author: nomper

title: COMPACT FOLDABLE Bottle Opener (designed in Switzerland)

description.text:
If you want a compact impressive bottle openenr or have a girlfriend who does not want to ruin their new nails, then you will have to print this thing!!!
Some time ago I saw this Smart One Handed Bottle Opener by Kart5a (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:269463), but I hate to have something edgy, relatively big and bulky in my pocket (nothing against the other design!). So I thought there can be done something. This is the result! A compact bottle opener which fits nicely into your pocket.
This is still in development and I hope you can give me suggestions to make it better.

Printed in PLA at 0.2mm layer hight at 210°C (depends on your PLA but print at a hight temperature so that the layers melt together well). I only used support between the joints, 15% infill and 3 outlines. Lay the two  principal parts flat on your printbed (I can't change this at the moment because the solidworks version just changed). Depending on how accurate your printer is, you will have to file the joints a bit (drawn +0.1mm between) and drill the hole (Ø5mm) to make it clean. Put the hollow pin (drawn -0.1mm ) in the hole and hammer the smaller one in with care, so it fits nicely. The money slot is actually created for a Swiss five cent piece and has a 1.2mm gap. I used a small flat head screwdriver to carefully spread it open and pinch it in. If you are not from Switzerland :-) you just need a piece of money with similar thickness and put it in there.

This is being tested as you read this, it is not finished or even working, print at your own risk  
This is a mod for the 1405 simple with the XL tower mod. it replaces the top plate of the tower so you can force the Z rods to one side or another, hopefully "shimming" the Z rods to be perpendicular to the X rods. I've also added the object i use to test the squareness of my printer.

• remove old plate
  • press fit a nut on either side of the slot
  • run a screw though
  • install plate
  • put spacer in between rods
  • testy with the long side in the Y axis with one shell and no top
  • use trig measuring from the top of testy to the end of your plate, measure the high and distance away from the end of the plate and plug it into a cosine law formula to find out what your printer is at
  • adjust screws as necessary

As part of my ongoing project with NASA/RISG on data actualization for the blind, visually challenged and just anyone wanting to get a hands on feel for extraterrestrial structures, here is a print of Gusev crater on Mars.  The actual crater is about 167 km in diameter and was the landing site for the now-stationary mars rover Spirit.

The mesh (not created by me, passed on by a student)was based on HiRise digital elevation terrain data. I brought the initial mesh into Rhino3d v.4 oriented it, traced the border, extruded the border, capped and clipped it.  It prints very well and the detail is not bad.  This version was printed in GITD ABS (the NASA office stole the red version). Straight forward print from the stl.

Update: I have redesigned this containter. You can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1558097 I needed a place to keep my Trinitite collection, along with a couple tiny samples of uranium ore and uranium glass. The little plastic jar that I had was getting a bit too cramped. So, I decided to design something much bigger and fancier, with UV reactive ABS and an obnoxiously large trefoil on the top. I'm sure you could use if for non-radioactive things as well. :)

If you are printing this to hold mildly radioactive samples, print both parts at 100% infill. I didn't use supports on the top, and the trefoil printed just fine without it. I used Makerbot Nuclear Green ABS(for obvious reasons), but the extra density of PLA may help with shielding a bit. Without going into all of the details around radiation shielding, 100% infill will block all alpha particles and a good percentage of beta particles. Plastic actually works better than metal when blocking beta particles, because beta particles can induce temporary radioactivity in certain metals. But, it all depends on how energetic the beta particles are, so it likely won't block all of them. You can always add some lead foil shielding to make it better. But, this is not exactly intended for laboratory conditions. This will do absolutely nothing to block gamma or X-rays! If you think otherwise, maybe you shouldn't be playing with radioactive things in the first place :) If you're printing this just as a container, 15-20% infill should be fine. The top and sides are particularly thick, so reduced infill will help to keep the plastic use down quite a bit. If you use Makerbot Nuclear Green and hit it with a UV lamp, it will light up like a christmas tree (as seen in the first photo). I painted the trefoil black, but it looks great unpainted as well.

description.text: Convert your boring old light switches into something more exciting!  Mix and match your button and box colors to suit your mood or decor.  You have the option of single, double, or triple switch configurations.

This conversion only works for rocker switches. New rockers with plenty of spring action work best. If you have toggle switches, you will need to change them out. Printing:
How many switches are you going to cover? Select and print the proper lid, box, and plate. Print the number of buttons and rings needed for your lid choice. The ring is the only part that will need to be printed using supports in MakerWare. Some parts have a .015 deep pocket on the backside to make it easier to remove the prints from the table surface. I hope this helps. Part Clean Up:
You may need to do some light sanding or filing (needle files work best) to get the parts to fit together properly. The inside surface of the rings will probably need the most work to ensure a smooth sliding of the buttons. The rings should fit firmly into the lid holes. Box Assembly:
Place all of your rings into the lid and set face down onto a flat surface. Only glue from the BACK SIDE (there is a photo for reference). Using a hot glue gun, lightly tack each ring in place making certain the ring and lid are fully together. Very little glue is needed It's better to glue the lid and box together after the rings are already glued in place to make certain the lid will fit firmly into the box. With the lid still flat on the table, set the box on lid. Don't squeeze the wall sides while glueing since it may affect the fit onto the adapter plate. Lightly tack into place with hot glue. Final Assembly:
Your rocker light switches will need to be spaced properly from the wall to get the best fit. The distance from the top face of the adapter plate to the wall should be about .250 . If it needs to be spaced further from the wall, you can print the light switch spacer and slip it onto the switch as shown in the example photo. Lightly tighten the adapter plate screws. If you tighten them too much, the mounting tabs will bend outward making it harder or impossible to snap the box into place. Slip your buttons into the rings. Slip the complete assembly onto the adapter plate starting with the bottom tabs and snap into place. The box should be flush with the wall. If there is a gap, remove the adapter plate, and screw the switches closer to the wall. If the tabs cannot snap onto the adapter plate then the swtiches need to spaced further from the wall. Play Time:
You can now Uppercut your lights on and Body Blow your lights off! You can also Zap your fan on and Hyperspace your fan off! Optional:
You can make it look even more like an arcade panel by decorating a piece of paper and glueing it onto the lid before the rings are tacked into place. You could even give names to the buttons.

title: vapor de acetona para piezas en ABS

description.text:
con este proceso se consigue que las piezas de ABS queden pulidas y brillantes
Síguenos en impresionante3d.com
y en www.facebook.com/impresionante3d

se puede utilizar cualquier recipiente resistente al calor y a la acetona 99%.
Ej. Una olla o un bote de cristal
Se pone encima de la cama de la impresora, esta se calienta a 110º para una vez alcanzados estabilizamos a 90º, nos equipamos con gafas protectoras guantes y mascara de gases ya que la acetona limpia todo hasta los pulmones. Vertimos una cantidad de acetona 99% dependiendo del volumen del recipiente, unos 5 milímetros de profundidad, tapamos pero dejando una salida de gases para no crear una explosión ya que la acetona es volátil y altamente inflamable pero mientras no se le acerque una llama y se le deje fluir es como el quitaesmalte para las uñas .
introducimos el objeto sin que toque el liquido, yo lo pongo sobre un espejo y cuando se seca sale fácilmente. con unas tuercas a modo de patitas para elevar un poco el objeto
lo tapo unos segundos pocos pero depende del volumen del objeto, si es muy pequeño 1 segundo sino se derrite y más volumen más tiempo , en el ejemplo esta unos 10 segundos
Sigue el video
http://youtu.be/jhSAOFk0dJk
Síguenos en impresionante3d.com

Basic version items are now all uploaded!
The order of the units will go Soldier, Sniper, Tank, Mortar, Civilian, and Worker.

For the basic version, it has the board, the very basic unit and the 0,2,4,6,8,10 die along with the 0-5 die. Start with 10 guys, the rectangles with the 3 slits for its health. For every turn they get 2 moves. To attack roll the 0-10 die, the defender rolls both the 0-10 die and the 0-5 die. The attackers damage is subtracted by the defenders number on the 0-5 die, then the defenders damage is halved and dealt to the attacker. For every turn, take the total amount of soldiers divided by 2, thats how many more you get.

title: Open Source Robotic Arm (Lite Arm i2)

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c-abxC1MJ2w
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qZBTVfS4Mxk
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5G7_IZY3am0
Dave Beck is making serious progress:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVurRLS4fFk
Update January 2nd, 2015
Changes are as follows:
We are working on the forward and inverse kinematics, and had to make changes to part 13B, 15B, and 18B, they are all followed by a "C" instead of "B" to note that a change has been made. The changes make the lengths precise to make perfect alignment in the geometry of the linkages. We will be adding the files for the electronics and software very soon. I archived the files from 2014 so the changes we make to the STL's moving forward will not erase the work from the past, so you can note the progression or access the early files for whatever reason.
We have a great team working on the development of this arm, and we hope to make this a very useful and dynamic tool in 2015! UPDATE 12.21.14
Changes: Added 14B_and_17B 2.1.stl (a cleaner part) Replaced 14B and 17B with:
14B_and_17B 2.0.stl due to unstable files Replaced 8B with 8B2.0 There was a discrepancy in part symmetry in association with part 7B. "Lite Arm Iteration 2" is a further improved iteration of the first project:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:407800 Special Thanks to contributors to this project!
My local team:
Robert Cordtz -R&D (Bay Area California)
Chris Beck -R&D (Bay Area California)
Emmanuel Mota -R&D (Bay Area California)
Myself- Lance Pierson -Structural Design & Chief Agitator (Bay Area California) My Online Contributors: (on Thingiverse)
David Beck /Dacb -Electronics and Software (Pacific Northwest)
Billie Jamerson /Reichenstein7 -Structural Design & Media (DC Metro) Thank you to everyone else I did not mention!

This is an amazing model of a Woolly Mammoth that I sourced from
the Smithsonian X 3D site. http://3d.si.edu/downloads/55
They have a lot of other cool models on their site, you should
check them out!
.
I separated the skull form the rest of the Mammoth and then sliced
it vertically to split off the tusks.
.
The print came out very well, but it is a challenging print requiring
both brim and support.
.
See instructions for the setings I used.

I printed the two pieces separately. If anyone is brave enough to
try it in one piece, or if you want to try to slice it differently,I do have
an unsliced copy of just the skull that I can send you.
.
I scaled these to 50% to fit on my print bed, then sliced them
using Cura with support and a 3mm brim. and I slowed the print
speed down considerably.
.
To orient the tusks, I used the following rotation values:
X 3.722655
Y 1.574096
Z 50.265361
.
The skull didn't seem to matter so much, I just oriented it so that the support material attached at the back of the skull.
.
I printed in PLA using .2mm layers and 20% infill; then (after a bit
of cleanup) glued them together with superglue.
.
Good Luck!

description.text: A remix of addamays123's Human Ear: modified with two pilot holes and countersunk holes so that you can screw in onto a wall. It also comes on a slighly raised platform, the idea being that it could function as a coat hook, although I haven't tested if it actually holds a coat. Meshmixer supports are included in the file, which also might cause it to be oriented on the Y-axis at import: simply rotate it 90 degrees to put the supports on the build platform.
Printed it with 0.1mm layers, 15% infill and a brim, on an Ultimaker 1 using Cura: no problem whatsoever.

comments.text: Hi Adam, we are printing on a hotbed so the idea is to configure the end g-code to wait for the bed temperature to cool down. This should in theory make it more reliable. However the m190 command does not wait for a temp to cool down, it only waits for a temp to warmup. So that's a firmware issue which needs to be solved.

title: Apple II keyboard - SMK Long Stem

description.text:
Replacement keyboard switch post or stem for Apple IIe. This part replaces the stem in an SMK "long stem" keyswitch, Apple part #s 705-0081, 705-0084, and 705-0082. See the images for more details, or archived Apple documentation here: https://archive.org/stream/DTCA2DOC-223_repair_IIe_1989#page/n53/mode/1up Also available in sets of 12:
https://www.shapeways.com/product/HHA3MNU4K/apple-iie-keyswitch-post-set-of-12 [updated August 2015] The stem now has a slight bulge in the plus-shaped cross-section to better acommodate variation in the size of the final print. Some pieces were too loose, and the keycap would come off too easily.

description.text: This is a molecular model of an RNA helix. RNAs are transcribed from DNA in the cell and are important to many cellular processes.

This will require support material to print properly. It's also available on Shapeways to print (at cost, no markup) if you do not have the ability to print this at home.
If people are interested I can try to make another version that has small bars in between the base-pairs to allow it to be printed without dissolvable support. (but I don't own a 3D printer so I'd need a volunteer to test it out).

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount Pan-Tilt Adapter

description.text:
This part adapts the Pimoroni Pi Camera mount as sold by Adafruit
(http://www.adafruit.com/products/1434)
to Pan-Tilt Kits similar to these:
http://www.adafruit.com/products/1967
http://www.adafruit.com/products/1968

This is a pretty specific Thing, but that's what 3D printing is for, right?  Anyway, this is set up to print upside-down so the recess for the hex nut is on top of the print.  As such, the cutout on the bottom may sag a bit when printing without support, but it didn't seem to be a problem in use.  
I sized the hex for a specific 1/4-20 nut I had on hand, and am not sure if it's a standard hex size or not, so you might want to check that before printing.   The bolt I used was a 1/4-20 x 1-3/8 SHCS which ended up being just the right length.  a 1-1/2 long bolt would probably work as well.  
My print snapped right into place on the Pan-Tilt rig without further modification, but it is pretty snug.  When I did the design, I forgot about the issue with 3D printed holes being undersized, so I ended up chasing the through hole with a 1/4 drill on my initial print, but I've already adjusted the file a bit to compensate for that.  
Also, the pic doesn't show it but I run the PiCam flat cable out the bottom of the camera and thread it through the pan-tilt rig in between the 2 servos.  It seems to handle the motion well when routed this way.  
Let me know if you have any problems with the files.

author: hamza

title: Filament travel counter (proof of concept only)

description.text:
Have you ever wished that you knew exactly how much filament was left on the spool so that you could plan out big 3D prints and spool-changes better? I set out to solve that by attaching a small mechanism on the 3D printer that would keep track of filament used. This is a proof of concept for a purely mechanical design. Filament is pulled through the device by the extruder, the filament spins a wheel, which in turn drives a set of gears that count upwards. The wheel and gears are sized to count out the length of filament passing through in centimeters. A typical 1kg of 1.75mm filament is 330m for PLA and 400m for ABS. My discoveries were:
  • 3D printed gears are pretty good, the printed parts have low friction, meaning that gears rotate freely, and even a 3D printed axle is low-friction enough for non-load-bearing gears.
  • Unfortunately, because of the low friction, the filament would slip past the wheel without spinning it. Some other material, like an elastic band, has to be added to generate enough friction between the wheel and filament for it to work.
  • A lot of careful design is needed to prevent jamming the geneva mechanisms, more rounded edges are needed basically everywhere two non-coplanar gears meet.
  • Part of the cause for jamming is size tolerances - every printer and even slicer setting will cause slightly different print sizes, and also printing artefacts, that affect the performance of the mechanism.
    • This isn't the finished design for a filament travel counter, it is a proof of concept only. It only counts on 4 digits, meaning it'll only count up to 99.99m of filament before rolling over, and is sized for 1.75mm filament (one extra dial needs to be added to work with 1kg spools, this can be easily done). And there is no mounting system to attach it to a 3D printer. I've decided not to continue with working on an all-mechanical filament counter. While this counter work in principle, so much effort will be involved in fine-tuning the design, that actually it would just be easier to use a 3D print manager that keeps track of filament usage in software. (Though the benefit of an all-mechanical counter is that you can print a separate counter for each spool that you have, giving you the freedom to switch spools without having to mess with your filament counter). Video of action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w5Znb5UNO8I

You will need to print out the following quantity of parts:
  • 1x frame1.stl
  • 1x frame2.stl
  • 1x driver.stl
  • 4x geneva.stl
  • 4x dial_numbered.stl
    • You will also need:
  • 1x small elastic band, or some self-amalgamating tape, or something else rubbery that you can wrap around the driver wheel.
    • Assembly:
  • After printing, smooth down the two axles and the holes in all the gears so that they spin freely
  • You may also wish to sand/cut down or round off all the gear teeth to make sure it doesn't jam
  • Wrap the small elastic band (or self-amalgamating tape) around the driver wheel
  • Slide the driver onto the large axle
  • Slide a small geneva gear onto the small axle. Make sure one of the longer teeth of the geneva gear lines up with one of the notches of the driver wheel
  • Slide the first dial onto the large axle, with the many-gear-teeth side facing towards the drive gear.
  • Slide the next geneva gear onto the small axle, make sure again that the longer teeth of the geneva gear lines up with the notch in the dial below it
  • Repeat for the remaining gears and geneva wheels
  • When done, the drive wheel should spin freely, and it should also increment the first dial as it rotates. You should also be able to observe all the dials ticking over from 9999 and 0000 (when you install the dials with all the notches in the right position, the number displayed on the dial should be between 9999 and 0000)
  • Install the shell. You may need to squeeze the square pins on the end of the axles to get it to fit into the hole in the frame.
  • Once assembled, push filament into the diamond holes. You may need to bend the end of the filament to get it to turn the corner inside
  • You should now be able to pull the filament through without too much force, and observe the dial ticking through the numbers. If things are too tight, you'll have to reduce the amount of elastic you wrap onto the driver wheel. If there's not enough friction, you'll have to increase the amount of elastic. This is the weakest point in this design (sorry), and part of the reason I'm discontinuing development of an all-mechanical counter.
  • Find some way of attaching this to the 3D printer or spool holder.
    • Good luck.

A wall-mountable holder for all sorts of cosmetic tools Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45656, my GF asked me to bring some order to her chaos in the bathroom. This thing features 35 holes, 50mm deep, to take brushes, lipsticks etc.

This thing consists of two parts.

  • The upper part takes the utensils, and can either be placed on a flat surface, or on the lower part. The diameter is 100mm

  • The (optional) lower part allows to wall-mount the thing (2x6mm holes), and allows rotary motion of the upper part
    • Printing both parts (5% infill, no support, PLA ) using Makerware and a Rep2 took about 12 hours.

comments.text: Great work! Just one tip for you: Make the inner cylinder (that one that you remove) slightly higher than the first. author: mikeandike1989

description.text:
This allows you to use a laser sight to build a tool to determine if two planes are parallel. This is primarily used for aligning a photo enlarger, but can be used for any two planar surfaces.
Uses a laser sight for a pistol and a mirror. An adjustable sight allows you to adjust the beam to be exactly perpendicular to the base. When the laser reflects back into the laser aperture the two surfaces are parallel.

Buy a laser sight for a pistol that clamps to an accessory rail. Make sure you get one which features adjustment screws to aim the laser. An inexpensive sight for an air soft or pellet pistol will be fine. You can get a nice one for $17 at Walmart, or less online. You will also need a small piece of mirror, which you can get at the hardware store. you might want to have the sharp edges dressed to make it safer to handle.
Once the part is printed clamp the laser sight onto the dovetail rail with the laser pointing up. The laser aperture should be approximately centered, but it doesn't make too much difference if it's not. These directions are to align a photo enlarger, but they apply to any other two planes you wish to make parallel.
Note: avoid letting the beam hit you in the eye.
Raise the enlarger head close to the maximum height (it will be more accurate this way). Place the mirror on the negative stage. Remove the lens from the enlarger.
Place the alignment tool on the baseboard and turn the laser on. Position it so the beam hits the mirror and reflects back down. Turn the alignment tool on the base board. If the beam is perpendicular to the base the reflected dot will stay in one spot. If it circles a spot as you rotate you will need to adjust the set screws on the sight. This is the hardest part, but it's pretty easy if you do it in several iterations. First find the center position of the circle the beam makes as you rotate the tool. Turn the set screws to bring the beam to that center spot. Keep rotating, adjusting and checking until the reflected beam hardly moves at all.
At this time you should adjust you negative stage or baseboard to make the beam reflect back on itself. If you can rotate the tool and the beam always reflects back into the hole it emerged from than the two planes are parallel and the laser is perpendicular to the tool.
Modified this for an 11mm bolt with a M5 Thread.
